content: hey guys welcome back to the second part of our cardboard ruins video and this is
really where the magic happens you know when you're slapping this stuff together
using cardboard and hot glue and construction sand it just looks kind of

of going to look like but it still really doesn't it just looks like a
bunch of stuff slapped together but once you get to this phase once you paint
this stuff that's when the magic really happens it really looks good so let's go
to the table and we'll show you how I do that
so here's our ruin i've spray-painted it flat black and i've got a dark brown
here and i'm just going to use my brush and fill in the base and i'm using this
applying this fairly wet so i put a little bit on the room in itself just to
give it a kind of dirty appearance and make sure that's all filled in good to
go now i'm going to use a lighter brown and a tan and I'm going to supplement
the first color I put on so the the darker Brown is dried and I'm going to
stipple on this lighter brown and look at what color variation to the base
there now I'll do a little bit of highlight with the tan so I'll just
stipple that on the base add some color areas there and good to go now I'm going
to do the ruin itself so I'm going to use a grey and I use my sponge and just
stipple that all over the the ruin there you can see how that painting that black
really gives it a nice shading without having a pain any shading because I'm
just filling in the areas in the recessed areas stay dark so it really
looks gives a nice shading effect to that without me really even doing
anything I'm just sipping on the eye gray so looking good now we're ready for
our next step all right so I want to do some highlight
and I'm going to use a color called pebble which is a cross between a ray
and a tan I'll just dry brush that a little bit on there just to get a little

night it looks kind of light right now but this will drive a little darker than

hit some of the flat surfaces on the ruin itself all right there we go

it really makes it look like a crumbling ruin and then just go around and just
you want to make them look all the same you want to bury the cracks somewhat and
just hit all the areas you know it looks nice really adds to it all right now to
accentuate that I'm going to use a light gray that light gray I use to highlight
the ruin itself and then I'm going to paint some of the edges of the cracks
okay and see how that makes those stand out it really makes them pop out and
that's a nice way you can do to just make it so that they're really three

nice variation of color we're getting there with those with that flocking
really looks good really nice alright looking good so
there we go coming up over the rocks really nice on the edges alright I want
